11112.content:
“Run away, Simba. Run away, and never return.”

His uncle’s bizarrely sympathetic words rang through his head, as Simba ran through the dusty gorge. His breathing was short and frantic, peppered with sobs as further tears leaked out of his brownish-red eyes. He wanted to just curl up into a ball and weep, or return to his father and sink into the surely still-warm pelt. But he couldn’t. Not when it was his fault.

He daren’t go back to Pride Rock. Uncle Scar was right; what would his mother think? Possibly, she would comfort him and hold him close, but before long she would find out. She would never give him that warm, gentle smile again. It would morph into a look of harrowing disappointment and shame, mingled with the grief of losing her husband.

His father.

Dad…I’m sorry. He didn’t know where the time to think came from, as he pressed his aching, sorrowful body into running, but he had to keep going. This was his punishment. If only he hadn’t tried to roar at that lizard, or if he had run to the side of the wildebeest instead of attempting to outrun them…he’d still be here.

“If it weren’t for you, he’d still be alive…”

He saw his father again, falling with an awful roar of terror and flailing his legs, trying to latch onto something, anything, but soon vanishing into the stampede. It nearly ripped Simba apart, but he had to keep going. He could now hear snarls from behind, and they were growing steadily louder. Fear began to set in, alongside the shock of what had happened to his father, which in itself was ebbing away to the grief. He would never hear his father’s voice again.

He would never spend evenings playing with him.

He would never see the look of pride on his father’s face, as he pounced on Zazu, accompanied by that booming laugh.

But, most importantly, he would never be able to tell him just how much he meant to him.

As the dust cleared momentarily, Simba could see that he had run out of gorge, and a flat wall of rock was in front. Eyes wide, he turned around. The three hyenas from the elephant graveyard had followed him. Maybe they were going to make him pay for what had happened then? Or maybe the Great Kings had seen what he had done to one of their own. This was their retribution.

Seeing their slobbering fangs and eyes set on murderous intent, the terrified cub looked back at the rocks, but saw no means of escape. This was it. All manner of fluids streaming down his face, Simba lay down on the ground, and curled up into a ball of golden fur. He shook with every raking sob, as he braced for the end which he knew was coming.

I’ll be with you again soon, Dad. If you still want to see me...

But, before long, he realised something was up. No claws ripped into his hide; no teeth snapped his bones to pieces; not a single drop of his blood was spilt. The growls that had accompanied the hyenas’ arrival fell silent. Confused, Simba lifted his heavy head out of his protective ball, and looked around. He wasn’t sure, given that he could neither think nor see straight, but it seemed as though the hyenas

Shenzi grinned widely as he raced after her quarry, the prince. Probably the king now actually, she supposed, if only momentarily. She paused a moment to sniff the trail, yep, the little brat had definitely gone this way, and fortunately for her, there wasn't a way out ahead, it was a dead end, dead in more ways than one...

Moments later, they'd reached the end, and their prize... Except for the fact that there wasn't a prize, no lion cub to do away with, but instead, she found, dozing fitfully, a hyena pup.

"What the-" Banzai began, but Shenzi shushed him, then investigated. Moving around the pup, the matriarch sniffed the edge of the walls, and even at the narrow scree slope that could potentially be used to get out for anyone foolishly desperate enough to risk it. But no, no scent of lion, or hyena, or any other animal if it came to it.

Suddenly, Shenzi heard a gasp, and turned to see the pup had awakened, and was looking at her, eyes filled with abject terror. Now admittedly, terror was a natural reaction when a pup was facing an adult it didn't know, but this was different somehow. Maybe it was something in the eyes that gave it away, but whatever it was she suddenly realised what had happened, crazy as it sounded, crazy as it was, this was Simba, no longer a lion cub, but somehow now a hyena pup. And a cute one too, she suddenly thought, then wondered why she had; it wasn't like she could just take him in out of the blue was it? Or could she? Sure it'd be unusual in the extreme, but-

"Hey Shenz', what's going on?" called out Banzai.

Shenzi was silent a few moments, still undecided as to what to do next. But she wouldn't have become a matriarch is she dallied on her thoughts, and so quickly made up her mind to...

1113322212211.content:
Simba saw something in the distance from the peak of Pride Rock. For some reason, he'd never seen it before - it was an arrangement of rocks. Despite its newness, he didn't expect the walk to it would be more than an hour, so he decided to check it out.

After the long walk, Simba arrived at what appeared to be a rock formation, only an ancient one, created well before he and his family had ever been at Pride Rock. Further, it appeared there were images on the rocks - a lion, like him, at first, then over time growing rounder. A second group of rocks showed a herd of wildebeests growing larger over time, and a third showed Pride Rock becoming an oasis. Another, smaller rock in the center just had a lion's pawprint. Interested, Simba placed his own paw on top of it.

He pulled it away when the rock began to glow, but he'd touched it long enough for the glowing to spread to his paw. Staring at it, Simba was shocked and worried as the glowing aura, aqua blue, quickly flashed through his body, vanishing after just a second.
1113322212211.title: Ruins depicting a prophecy

11133222122112.content:
Frightened and confused, Simba wasn't sure what had just happened, but he knew he wasn't too happy with it, and more importantly, needed to figure out what those stones meant. So he dashed as quickly as he could to Rafiki's tree, hoping the mandrill would know what to do.

Once the monkey heard the story, he couldn't believe it. "What luck!", he cried, "you truly will be the greatest king of them all."

"What? What do you mean?", Simba replied.

"Well, it's the prophecy, of course! Long ago, I was told of ruins that foretold great prosperity. Just as you said, the wildebeest herds will span to the edge of the savannah, and Pride Rock will become a paradise, all because of your bravery to investigate it. The king with a good enough heart, of which there are very few, can follow it! You have brought an age of great joy to your home!"

Simba was ecstatic to hear his simple action had guaranteed success for his generation and the next few to come, but still found himself with a question. "What about the growing lion?", he asked. "The stones showed a lion growing larger and wider. That's not me, is it?"

Rafiki grinned. "Well, of course it is!", he said. "I'm surprised you haven't already noticed!"

"Noticed what?"
11133222122112.title: He returns to Pride Rock at once.

111332221221121.content:
Simba could only look at parts of himself, but he was surprised at what he saw. While it wasn't hugely noticeable yet, his paunch was drooping just a bit lower, and his haunches were ever-so-slightly more swollen. "I've..."

"It's started!", Rafiki said. "So quickly! You're a good 20 pounds bigger than last week!"

Simba quickly grew concerned. "What's happening to me, Rafiki?"

"The ruins' prophecy says you'll become as large as Pride Rock's future is bright! You'll be getting a lot bigger than that!"

Simba gulped. "And when will that be?"
111332221221121.title: "Look at yourself!"

1113322212211211.content:
"Oh, about five minutes," Rafiki said.

Simba was shocked. When he was considering being fat, he didn't think about it happening so soon, or so drastically. He had no idea what to expect, and began to start breathing heavily. Just in time for Rafiki to cackle more. "It's time to become the true king!", the mandrill said.

Simba could only see parts of himself, but he felt his entire body suddenly add pounds at a furious rate all around him. From what he could see, his paws quickly widened, his legs and haunches quickly following. He bent to look at his rump, which was swelling out, up, down and around, until the size of his sides forced him to turn back forward. Rafiki laughed and clapped, as from his perspective, the lion absolutely transformed into another being entirely. His face widened, his neck shrank and disappeared, and his stomach spread around, not only out, to avoid his belly dragging on the ground. Though it only hung above the dirt by less than a foot.

Eventually, Simba closed his eyes, wishing this was just a dream, until he was awoken by a swift bonk to the head by Rafiki. "Lion! Open your eyes and see what you have become!"

Simba did as he was told, seeing the monkey's work - as he grew, the monkey had smeared a fruit on the wall behind him, which suddenly began showing a reflection. To his shock, Simba had...

11233121.content:
The customary period of mourning for a dead king had ended; Mufasa had loved his father dearly and already missed him sorely. The young lion was little more than an adolescent, scrawny and inexperienced in the art of hunting and ruling. Mufasa had just begun to observe his father rule when the good king had died suddenly and without any sign of malaise which usually preceded death. The surgeon-priest Rafiki hitherto had not diagnosed any problems with the older lion's health. "Everything looks acceptable. Perhaps the ancestors were angry with him for some wicked decision he has made."
         Mufasa found that explanation horribly lacking. This sort of death was not unheard of, and it happened to both the just and the unjust. Perhaps it was just some law of the savanna that this should happen. But Mufasa didn't want to start a fight with Rafiki over something that both were merely speculating about, so he kept quiet and nodded along as Rafiki gave his explanation to the assembled entourage of guests, who gasped at the cause of the old king's death. Sarabi, Mufasa's mate, turned to him and whispered, "Is Rafiki insane? We really ought to get rid of him."
         Mufasa pondered for a moment before he spoke aloud, loud enough for everyone to hear, in a shaky, nasally, adolescent way with voice-cracks and all, "Rafiki, I ask you--for I do not claim that you are wrong yet--but I ask you: what wrongdoing has my father committed that caused the ancestors to be angry?"
         Rafiki had stopped, looked up, and addressed Mufasa, "Your majesty, if you please, I was getting to that. But as I was saying, we do not know what evil the good king has committed that our next sovereign, King Mufasa, must contend with; but I do know that there is some evil we must fight. Therefore, your majesty, you must call a council of all your subjects, a delegation of every beast in this land to Pride Rock to hear their grievances against the pride of lions. So do I advise his highness King Mufasa to ordain." And here, Rafiki took a less formal tone, "Speaking of ordaining, your majesty, we must anoint you as king of the savanna."
         Mufasa nodded nervously and stepped forward, but Rafiki moved to dismiss all the other animals from the crypt of pride rock before he would ordain Mufasa king. But Mufasa called Rafiki to stop, "Rafiki, please, let them stay, let them see their king anointed in all his splendor."
         But Rafiki protested, "Your majesty, with all respect, this process is sacrosanct. We can't have these other animals looking at us while I anoint you."
         But Mufasa stood firm: "Rafiki, if you refuse my command, I will ask you to step down and let someone else take your place." Here Rafiki balked between obeying the king's orders and respecting the will of the ancestors, but eventually he obeyed the crowned prince, "As you like it, majesty."
         Thus Rafiki, having all the necessary ingredients for the ceremony, called Mufasa to a raised bed of rock that served as a platform for all to see. "King Mufasa," Rafiki began, "you must honestly swear to all of the following things: do you swear to uphold the good of the kingdom?"
         "I do."
         "Do you swear to obey the will of the ancestors?"
         "I do."
         And so went a litany of vows that Mufasa made before a mixture of what appeared to be the blood of his father and various herbs mixed into a paste was imprinted upon his forehead. The gathered multitude of animals cheered, but before they had left, Mufasa turned to them: "My subjects, in seven nights after tonight, counting tonight, we shall have a great council for as long as need be until I should hear all of your grievances. Tell all the members of each of your races and any races not represented here today that there will be such a meeting. Gather all of your grievances and send a delegation of the finest of your races to come to me and submit them; and I will do all that is reasonable to correct them." Thus Mufasa decreed and all the animals present heard him and obeyed.

         The arrangements necessary for the great assembly overwhelmed Mufasa immediately. There was resistance form Taka, Mufasa's brother, who claimed that the animals would all demand that the lions stop hunting them but that no other grievance would or even could be aired. Sarabi immediately protested that to call an assembly such as Mufasa had done was a sign of disunity and a lack of prosperity, which would cause scandal and attract rogues. "Perhaps if you would help me arrange and stop complaining," Mufasa spat at his mate, "we wouldn't appear to be in such a mess." And Mufasa only ignored Taka, who liked to criticize without proposing solutions to fix problems that arose, in other words, he like to whine.
         Mufasa slept little in the days leading up to the assembly because he was restless and nervous about the assembly. 12121.content:
"Now, are you sure you're ready for this," Simba asked, both of his daughter Kiara and her mate and king, Kovu, "I can stay around if you're still-"

"Father, we've been ready for this for years," Kiara interjected, "we really have, you and mum have trained us well."

"As you wish," Simba replied, "but you know, if you do run into-"

"Simba, it's time to let go," Nala interrupted, then continued more kindly, "we've done what we can, it's time to let them make their own way in life."

"I suppose you're right my love," Simba sighed, "farewell you two, I hope I'll see you again soon enough."

"Have a safe journey guys," Kiara said, by way of response, "and don't worry, we'll keep it together."

"I'm sure you'll do us proud," Nala agreed, "now come on Simba."
-------
Simba winced at the aches in his limbs as he climbed the steep, rocky hill. Pausing for breath at the top, he didn't realise it, but he was within just a few feet of the place he'd once stood all those years ago. Nala, leding by a few lengths remembered though, because she said after a few moments "it looks a lot better now than it did the last time we were here."

"What," Simba asked, then turned in the direction Nala had indicated, "yes, it is quite...wait, we stood here?"

"On this ledge, yes," Nala replied, "you remember it?"

"I remember feeling hopeless, helpless," Simba replied, "and then you turned up."

"Of course it's not really the same ledge any more," Nala replied, "we're different now, and so is the land."

"We're the better for it, all of us," Simba replied, then winced as he shifted slightly and felt a twinge, "well in some ways."

"In all the ways that count," Nala replied, then rose, "come on, we've a lot more ground to cover yet."
-------
"Whew," Simba said finally as he entered the shadowy jungle, with dawn just beginning to break over the horizon, "that was some trip."

"Sure was," Nala replied, "I want a nap, and I want it to last about a half-a-moon."

"Speak for yourself," Simba replied, "I'm parched, I want to have a drink before I settle down."

"That's an idea too," Nala said, "but you know, we've been going almost a day, a rest will do us good."

"I still want a drink," Simba replied, then added in an alluring tone, "and I'm sure you want one too."

"Well I do to a degree," Nala replied, "..."
12121.title: Elder Journeyers

121211.content:
"...But I still want a nap first, I'll see you later."

"It'll be back soon," Simba replied, as he disappeared into the shadowy jungle.

Nala watched her mate disappear, then started to look around for a comfortable spot to sleep, once she would have slept anywhere, but these days she was more picky about where she slept, the wrong place would set off her aches, never a pleasant experience. It took a while, but in the end, after a bit of exploring she found somewhere she was willing to lie down.

Of course it wasn't perfect, the cool morning air caused her to shiver as she lay back, she hadn't realised until now how great an advantage another body or two was in preserving comfort. Still, she thought, it would only be temporary, soon enough Simba would be back, and then the cold wouldn't be so much of an issue.
-------
Simba growled to himself if frustration, where was that waterhole, surely he couldn't have forgotten where it was surely, he'd grown up in the jungle, he knew every paws-breath of it. The more he wandered however, the less certain he became of his own sense of direction, it had been many years since he'd been here after all, and his memory was prone these days to confusion. To further add to his troubles, most of his memories were of the jungle in as much sunlight as filtered through the canopy, whereas now he was moving in the long shadows of the very early dawn. Resolutely though, he carried on.

More time passed as Simba wandered on blindly, ever deeper into the jungle. By now he was taking frequent rests, almost a day of hard travelling had taken more from him than he'd first realised, and with the undulating, obstacle-strewn nature of the forest, his aches were beginning to play up badly. Eventually, the elderly lion was almost ready to give in and return to his mate when he sensed a clearing up ahead, and moved towards it, hoping that he'd finally find, if not the waterhole he'd been intending then at least somewhere to quench his thirst.

The clearing did indeed contain a waterhole, but not one Simba had ever seen before. The whole place seemed to have an odd, almost mystical feel to it, which put him slightly on edge. As he approached the waterhole, the feelings only grew, the almost perfect roundness of the waterhole, and the trickling of water out of a pipe in the opposite wall only adding to the strangeness. Still, he was thirst, and there was water, and so the elderly lion spent only a little time in examining the surroundings before moving slowly towards the pool.

The water was cool and fresh, and somehow sweet, Simba though as he lapped at it, first tentatively, then thirstily. Yes, this was what he needed, he thought, he was dry, parched, and the water was filling the gaps, easing his aches and making him feel more full of life than he had in...a long time. After drinking his fill, he set off once again, this time in the opposite direction, at a brisker pace.
-------
Nala snorted as the bug tried to work its way into he nose, blowing it out. This intrusion, combined with the unusually humid, clingy air of the jungle was enough to waken the elderly lioness, though that same humidity made her feel listless and tired. A slightly unsettling feeling motivated her to sit up, groaning at the stiffness that lying in a nest even as comfortable as this brought on. She pushed the thoughts to the side though as she scanned her surroundings...

1243321.content:
Vitani sighed as she sat up the end of the promontory of Pride Rock, watching the sun dip below the horizon. She knew she should be heading down now, to find a place in the cave with the others, but for now she just wanted to be alone. It wasn't that she disliked the others, it was just that, well, having been her mother's so-caller right paw for so long she didn't really feel comfortable in large groups. It was times like that that got her to thinking, what if mother had been sane rather than crazy, and had seen the madness in her ideals, what would growing up in the Pridelands have been like? Her reverie was interrupted when she felt a brush against her side, and looked around to find Ki-princess Kiara sitting beside her, "princess."

"Oh cut out the formalities Vitani," Kiara laughed, "there are times I enjoy being a princess, and other where I wish with all my heart I wasn't, and this is one of those times."

"You don't want to be princess," Vitani asked, shocked.

"No I don't," Kiara replied, "because you know what, it gets tiring, everyone being so respectful around you, trying not to hurt your feelings, you get the idea right."

"Well, yeah, I can see how that would be tiring I suppose," Vitani replied, "I guess I-hey, did you see that?"

"See what," Kiara asked.

"Just for a moment I thought I say a streak of light up there," Vitani said.

"Better make a wish then," Kiara said.

"What, why," Vitani asked.

"No reason I suppose," Kiara said, "it's just something mother used to tell me when I was young, if you saw a streak, and made a wish, the wish would come true."

"That sounds..." Vitani said, trying to think of a diplomatic word.

"Yeah, I know, sounds daft," Kiara said, then stood up, "you coming soon?"

"Soon," Vitani agreed. She heard Kiara leave, then shook her head at the though, whoever thought of wishing on a streak? Still though, she thought, it was silly things like that that it might have been nice to have once. Sighing again, she got up and descended the promontory, before making her way over to the cave and settling down near the entrance. With her mind still heavy with her earlier thoughts, sleep came slowly, but she did eventually nod off.
-------
Vitani awoke early the next morning, feeling unsettled, something wasn't right, but she couldn't be sure quite what-

"Oh, you're awake early this morning Vitani," said a voice that was familiar, and yet not.

Turning, Vitani saw herself looking up at a lioness that like the voice, was familiar, and yet different, "yeah, I-"

"Is something the matter dear," the lioness asked.

"What, no, no," Vitani said, "I'm just a bit tired still I guess." Who was this lioness, she looked like-no, that was impossible-

"Are you sure there's nothing wrong," Zira asked, and it was Zira she realised, Zira, her mother, but this wasn't the Outlands, this looked exactly like the sleeping cave at Pride Rock- Suddenly her thoughts were interrupted by...
1243321.title: Loner Lioness

1243323.content: So even time travel and superpowers aren't what you're after? What do you want then?
1243323.title: Changing Faces

12433231.content:
Vitani stared up at the night sky, her expression a sorrowful grimace. Her eyes were moist, but she insisted to herself that she wasn't crying, crying was something done by cubs unable to control their emotions, and since she was an adult what she was doing wasn't crying, it was just, letting her tears flow. She was angry too of course, oh not at anyone in particular, not even at Simba for he was, she had to admit, entirely innocent in this affair, but just angry in General that he brother had been taken from her.

Vitani's eyes were drawn upwards suddenly when a streak of starlight blazed for a moment. A 'visiting king' Nuka had called it when he'd first told her about it back in the innocent days of her early cubhood. Of course, she hadn't really accepted it even then, their life had been too hard even then, and harsh living and harsher training at her mother's paws had long since worn away any pretensions of fantasy. Still, deep down in her soul, a tiny germ of hope sprang up, what if, maybe, this was the one time that things were different? She chuffed at that, no, no that would never happen, wishing on a 'visiting king' was a fantasy for cubs.

This time however, somehow, a wish was granted, and wishing was indeed a fantasy for cubs, only this time not in the way Vitani would have ever considered.
-------
Vitani lay back looking out over the Pridelands, now her home. She was alone at the moment, and that suited her fine, for although she enjoyed company almost as much as any lioness, there were times when solace was welcome too. All was well now, she lived in perfect happiness, at least most of the time, though now she was taking the time to remember, remember her family departed and her life left behind. Not a day went by when she didn't think about them, but the memories were less distinct now, more distant, the Pridelands was working its way into her soul and mind, blunting the sharp edges of her past.

The past wasn't quite finished with Vitani just yet though, for although she'd long since forgotten the wish she'd made on her last night in her old life, the wish had been granted. The effect of this had not yet begin to show, eclipsed by more rapid and for now larger changes that came with a much improved lifestyle, but those were slowing down now, while this one was only increasing, and eventually it would be unmistakable.

After a moon in her new life, Vitani...
12433231.title: Mother to her Brother

124332311.content:
...Began to feel slightly odd, not ill precisely, but strange. There seemed to be a weight in her gut as though she'd eaten a large meal, but constant, and indeed separate from anything in her stomach. At first she was content to hide it, but as time went by she became more and more concerned, and so knew she'd have to consult someone eventually.

The problem was, who to talk to, She didn't want her former Outlander pridesisters to know lest they ridicule her, she didn't trust Kiara to keep her mouth shut about it, nor Kovu for that matter, and she didn't really feel confident enough around most of the former Pridelanders to try to ask delicate question, which finally left but one option, Queen Nala. Of course, catching the queen alone wasn't easy, but finally she managed it, or at least close enough, one day when they were dragging carcasses back to Pride Rock and she managed to end up on the same one as the queen. "R'm, Qu'n N'ra," she said, her mouth full of zebra leg.

"Y's, V't'ni," Nala replied, her mouth clamped around the carcass's throat, its head having been turned over almost onto its back."

"C'n I t'lk 't y'u 'ft'rw'rds, 'n pr'v't?"

Nala glanced back at Vitani, as noticed a certain nervousness, even trepidation to the young lioness, which she found slightly odd for she knew the younger lioness was usually quite confident, "'f y'u w'nt."
-------
"So what's wrong," Nala asked Vitani when they seemed to be far enough away for the younger lioness's comfort.

"There's this weight that's been growing in my belly for a while now," Vitani replied, "it's, I don't know what it is."

"Have you been to see Rafiki about it," Nala asked.

"Rafiki," Vitani asked, "who's-wait, is that that, monkey?"

"You've never-" Nala began, then she thought about it, "of course, you'd never have met him would you, well maybe it's time you did, come on."
-------
"Look, let's get one thing straight okay," Vitani said impatiently, "I haven't ever mate with a male okay, not in my entire life."

"Then I am at a loss to explain your pregnancy," Rafiki replied.

"I'm pregnant," Vitani asked, shocked, "no I can't be, is, isn't there anything else it could be?"

"Well, one or two things perhaps," Rafiki replied, "but they are much less likely and much much more serious."

"No, it can't be," Vitani shook her head and turned to Nala, "it can't be possible can it?"

"Up until today I would have agreed with you," Nala replied, "but the way you described it, well, I've been through it, and it sounded exactly like that."

"But I've never mated," Vitani said, by now almost frantic, "how can I be pregnant?"

"If you are not pregnant," Rafiki said gravely, "whatever you have will kill you before the next moon is out."

At this, Vitani's expression of desperation segued into horror, and before either Nala could think to stop her, she was off and running, not even bothering to look back as the queen called, "Vitani wait, Vitani."
-------
At first Vitani wasn't sure where she was going, and indeed only noticed her surroundings when she reached a cave-no, the cave, the one where she'd spent every night before betraying her mother. Finally free, she sat down, and for the first time in her life she wept, not out of sadness, but out of fear. Alone and terrified, she cried herself to sleep. Slumber brought little solace however, and she was soon awoken by...

15212212212.content:
How about this scenario; After a near-disaster while on a mission with the Guard, Kion begins to think that his father has the easier job, being a King and everything, at least in comparison to his own, as leader of The Lion Guard.
Meanwhile, Simba starts to feel overwhelmed with all of the responsibility that comes with being the ruler of The Pride Lands and begins to believe that being the leader of The Lion Guard, as his son, Kion, is, would be a breeze, compared to what he himself is used to as King.
After Kion and Simba talk to each other about who of them have the easier job, they go to Rafiki for help. Rafiki then uses his shamanic abilities to swap Kion's and Simba's bodies with each other, not only because they asked him to, but also to teach them that the grass is not always greener on the other side of the Savannah.
15212212212.title: Story line: "A better job... maybe...."

152122122122.content:
Here's another scenario; One night, Kion observes a shooting star that falls down into the Pride Lands. The next morning, he goes out to where he saw it fall and finds a strange, glowing stone. Kion then decides to show the stone to his father, but when he does so, the stone swaps Kion into Simba's body and Simba into Kion's body, for a whole week.
So, for that entire week, Kion and Simba now have to pretend to be each other. But it's not as easy as they initially think it'll be; Simba will not only have to get used to being in the body of a cub again, (his own son's body, nonetheless), that's at least four times smaller than the body he is used to, he'll also have to get used to making split-second decisions while on missions with the Guard; something he has great difficulty doing, since as the King he has a lot more time to think about important decisions. Plus, Simba does not have the same relationship as Kion does with the rest of the Guard, which makes it harder for him to pretend to be Kion, since the Guard does not know that Simba switched bodies with Kion.
As for Kion; he'll not only have to get used to being in the body of a fully grown-up lion, (his own father's body, nonetheless), that's at least four times as big as the body he is used to, he'll also have to get used to making important decisions that concerns all of The Pride Lands; something he has great difficulty doing, since he's just a cub and as such is inexperienced at that sort of thing. Plus, since Nala is not aware that Simba and Kion have switched bodies, it will be extremely awkward for Kion, since Nala is his mother. Nuff said.
152122122122.title: Story line: "The strange stone..."

1521222112.content:
Inside the Lion Guard's den, a female could be heard laughing.

This laughter continued on for a few minutes, until a staff hit the laugher on the head.

The female voice yelped, "Ouch!"

Rubbing her head with one of her paws, she glared at the person who whacked her, Rafikki, "What'd you do that for?"

Rafikki rolled his eyes, before pointing to a male lion cub who appeared to be in shock.

The female hyena's ears went down, "Oh, Jasiri must be in shock. I better go talk to her-er-him."

The hyena trotted over to her former body, unable to keep the spring out of her step, and asked, "So, how you holding up?"

The lion cub's head quickly spun to face the hyena, and said, "I-Kion...what?"

Kion smiled sheepishly at her former body, "I told you Rafikki could swap our bodies."
1521222112.title: Just after the swap

15212221121.content:
Kion sheepish grin turned into a sincere one when he/she noticed that Jasiri was grinning.

Jasiri examined her/his new body with a small smile, and when finished with the examination, looked at the hyena cub, and gave a small, but emotional, smile.

Kion, meanwhile, shuffled around awkwardly in Jasiri's original body, 'W-What's going on? Why do I feel like butterflies are dancing in my stomach? What did Jasiri eat?'

Jasiri acted like she/he didn't notice how her/his original body was acting, but thought, 'Well, let's see how Kion likes a certain lion screwing up every thought and just refusing to leave.'

Jasiri stepped closer to Kion, inwardly relishing the look on her/his original face, and simply stood there for a few seconds.

Kion spoke up, "Jasiri, what-"

Kion immediately shut up when Jasiri bent her/his head and licked the side of Kion's face. Jasiri moved her/his mouth next to Kion's ear, "Thank you for this, it's great."

Kion was feeling light-headed, and uneasy on his/her paws, but was also enjoying the feeling.

Jasiri smirked, planning to re-enact her/his reoccurring dream, but from the other side of what she/he was used to.
15212221121.title: Jasiri's overjoyed

152122211211.content:
Kion was blinking rapidly, 'What's going on? Why do I feel like this?'

Jasiri started to sniff and nuzzle Kion's new legs (this is how hyenas show affection).

Kion felt the butterflies in his/her stomach melt into one really big and warm feeling, Kion wanted to ask Jasiri about it, but was unsure if he/she would be able to get a proper word out with the warm feeling.

Without warning, Jasiri jumped away and ran towards the entrance to the den.

Kion blinked, the warm feeling growing colder as he/she wondered why Jasiri did that, before running after the lion cub.

Rafiki just muttered to himself, "I wonder if they forgot I was here."

At the entrance to the den, Kion saw Jasiri on her/his hind legs, with the forepaws rested on a rock for balance. When Kion got closer, Jasiri turned her/his head to look at Kion. At the sight of the lion cub smiling, Kion felt the warm feeling return.

Jasiri said, "Hey, Kion, you better show me around. You know, so I can do your job."

Kion rolled his/her eyes at the playful insult, before saying, "Good idea. So, if you'll just follow me."

Kion walked ahead, with Jasiri following with a small smirk.

As Kion pointed out landmarks and told Jasiri various names, Jasiri made sure to compliment Kion on his/her intelligence, memory, or compassion. Just like how the Kion from Jasiri's dreams did to her/him.

Unfortunately for Jasiri, the tour eventually ended.
152122211211.title: Continue

15212221122.content:
Kion's grin faltered when Jasiri scowled at her/his former body, and spoke slowly, enunciating each word, "Kion, I thought you were joking! We can't do this! I-I mean how would I even pretend to be you? How could you pretend to be me? Have you thought this through at all?"

Kion looked away from Jasiri's angry eyes, "I did think this through, you're the person I can trust the most with my body. Bunga would get my body hurt, Beshte and Fuli would have to much trouble in adjusting, Ono wouldn't be able to fly, and everyone else would tell my dad."

Jasiri started growling, "So, I'm just a last resort then, huh?"

Kion shook his/her head quickly, eyes wide, "No! You were actually the first person I thought of, then I started thinking about other people! I swear!"

Rafiki stood in the background, "This is getting awkward, I'm leaving."

Rafiki then ran out of the den, leaving the two alone in awkward silence.

Kion spoke up, "Jasiri, please listen -"

Jasiri interrupted, "No, Kion." Jasiri took a deep breathe before continuing, "Right now, I'm really angry. I don't really want to talk right now. But, I will do this, if only because we can't change back without that monkey. But, remember, you owe me for this, got it?"

Kion nodded.

1521322222221121.content:
"Why did you take me here, dad?" asked Kion. His father, Simba, had taken him to a strange watering hole in the middle of a cave.

"You'll find out," answered Simba. "Tell me, Kion; have you ever wanted to be an adult instead of a cub?"

"Sometimes," said Kion. "Mostly when Janja calls me 'lion cub' in that mocking way."

"Well, sometimes I want to be a cub again," said Simba. "To go back to being carefree and take a little break from being a king. Which makes this the perfect chance for both of us."

"Huh?" said Kion, looking very confused. Simba chuckled.

"Rafiki once told me about certain places in the Pride Lands where there are mystical watering holes. He said, that if you drink from one of them, strange things will happen to you. You could turn into a different kind of animal, you could grow bigger than a giraffe is tall, or many other things."

Wow! That is awesome!" exclaimed Kion.

"Exactly," said Simba. "And we are heading for one of them right now."

A moment later, Kion and Simba entered a vast cavern with a glowing watering hole on one side. As Kion looked into the glowing water, Simba said: "This particular watering hole is a bit different from the others. This one needs two animals to drink from it at the same time. But when they do, it exchanges their ages. They still have all of their memories and personality, but they will physically become the age that the other animal is."

Kion looked up at his dad. "So... If you and I were to drink from this hole at the same time, then I would be a fully grown lion and you would be a cub again?"

"That's right," said Simba. "And that is why I brought you here: To give you the chance to be the adult for a while."

After seeing that Kion looked a bit nervous, Simba guessed what the problem was and quickly said: "The effects are only temporary. We will return to normal after about three days. Does that comfort you?"

"It does. Thanks, dad!" said the now perked-up Kion, as he moved to the edge of the watering hole, his dad walking up beside him.

"Now; are you ready?" asked Simba.

"You bet!" was Kion's reply.

Simultaniously, the two lions bent down and drank from the water. When they were done, they both felt a strange feeling spreading through their bodies.

Kion looked in awe as the changes began. He could see his dad slowly getting smaller. His mane began to retract into his skin, his muscles diminished and he started to shrink as the years slowly went in reverse for him.

As Kion watched his dad getting younger, he could feel himself getting older. He felt his own mane beginning to grow in, as he himself slowly grew, while muscles were added to his body.

With the years changing between them, it wasn't long until father and son were equal in age. But that didn't last long, as Kion continued to grow older, while Simba kept getting younger.

When the changes stopped, Kion had become an adult lion, while Simba had become a cub again.

"Hevi kabisa! I'm..... big....." Kion exclaimed in his new, deeper voice.

"I told you it would be interesting," said the young Simba.

"There's an understatement," said Kion. It was strange for him to see his dad being a cub again, but it was even stranger to be an adult.

What do they decide to do next?

15213222222221222221.content:
Near the outskirts of the Outlands, a lion cub with small tuft of mane on his head arrived on the scene. Kion wanted to hang out with Jasiri mostly out of boredom as nothing drastic had been happening in the Pridelands recently.

However, he wanted to explore the area a little bit before meeting up her, fortunately he didn't meet up with any of the hostile inhabitants such as Janja's gang. As he walked around the barren wastelands, passing by various rock formations, gorges, and dried shrubbery, he came across a grim and dismal site. It was a graveyard valley of sorts filled with bones strewn about, mostly elephants, zebras and other kinds that are more prey than predator. It was a dead end, emphasis on dead, as the valley was closed with great big cliffs/rock walls all around.

But his eye caught something unusual about one section of that wall. It was actually a large pile of bones! Curiously, he walked towards it and looked up. It seemed to be climbable enough if he was careful and what is on the other side is anyone's guess which is also a reason for him to check it out. After the climb over, he discovered something rather interesting. It was a cave whose mouth looked to be around over 30ft in height, having two stalagmites and two stalactites act as fangs, and pitch black inside that even sunlight couldn't reveal more than a few feet within.

It definitely proved to be intimidating for the lion cub and felt it necessary to have someone else accompany him with his findings with Jasiri being the closest one nearby. But still he was this far and want to at least take a quick look inside with how strong his curiosity was making him.

What happens next?
15213222222221222221.title: Cave of Wonders

'Might as well since I'm here.'

He decided to go it alone as curiosity won over and with a deep breath, he went into its dark depth. To his surprise after going a few feet in, he met an incline with natural steps. It wasn't long until the path leveled out and light and visibility lessened and his eyes had to adjust in the darkness. Didn't help that a sense of claustrophobia kicked in too yet still continued on.

The passageway he was on curved in places and then some until it started to broaden more. Soon after nearly what felt like an hour, the path opened up into a great big room that was surprisingly lit by strange glowing crystals/rocks on the walls and ceiling. More surprising was what was in the middle of the room.

What is it?

1521322222222122222222.title: An "Alice in Wonderland" Adventure?

15213222222221222222221.content:
On a sweltering savanna day, a young lion cub lied down beneath a shady bushy tree of a nearby waterfall/watering hole, a jungle like area a bit ways between Pride Rock and the Outlands. And the heat wave was the only threat that pervaded the Pridelands at the moment. Nothing the Lion Guard could do. In fact, the rest of the guard were off cooling down with their families and friends.

While the lion's den back at Pride Rock was cool and shady enough, Kion thought this little jungle like paradise was just as good and next to a water source to drink and swim in.

"YAWN!"

However, his body was yearning for some rest and long nap as his eyelids felt heavy. Soon, he fell into a deep slumber.

It wasn't until around ten minutes later that something unusual happened. His body glowed in a golden light and he began to shrink! Soon, he was the size of a grub with the world becoming much larger as blades of grass became as tall as trees. After a while, Kion tossed a bit before waking up, stretching and yawning as he got up. He slowly opened his eyes to discover his surroundings had drastically changed.

"What happened to me?!" he said looking around in panic of the bigger world he was in. Then, he heard a familiar voice as it flew pass him.

"I'm late! I'm late! I'm terribly terribly late!"

"Zazu?!"

It was the red billed hornbill yet as small as he was and didn't seem to notice or care about. He kept repeating about being late but for what?

"Hey, wait up!"

Kion called out as he attempt to catch up with the bird before he dove into a meerkat hole at the base of a nearby tree. The lion cub followed suit into the hole before tumbling down into it. After getting up and shaking off some dirt, he found himself at the beginning of a tunnel. Zazu seemed to have went farther ahead into as he couldn't see him anymore down the passage yet could still hear his mantra of being late. After going down some ways, he encountered a three way fork in the road and decided which path to take.

Which way did he go?
15213222222221222222221.title: Through the Meerkat Hole

152132222222212222222212.content:
Kion just went down the middle path, not wanting to wait any longer so he can catch up to Zazu. After some time, the pathway began to shrink as the corridor became cramped with his mane nearly scrapping the ceiling. How darker it was complicated things further.

'Maybe I should head back and take a different way.' he thought to himself. However, before he could turn around, his next step made him tumble onto a slide.

"WHOA!" he cried as he rode down with twists and turns around every corner. The ride took a few minutes before it dropped him into a room.

"OOF!"

He landed onto his back after falling a couple feet off the ground. Kion got up and shook off some dirt before taking a look at his surroundings. The room was rather large, like the size of a fully grown tree, made up of clay colored rock like the lion's den but unnaturally near smooth and perfectly square. The floor was a gray slate, also smoothed out. The walls were adorned with some cave drawings of various animals, similar to the ones Rafiki makes.

But what caught his attention was a smooth flat round rock in the center of the room as tall as he was. On top were two half coconuts, like it was perfectly cut down the middle. As he approached them out of curiosity, he discovered the halves were filled with some kind of liquid, the left blue while the right red. His nose caught a fruity scent from them. What would they taste like?

"I'm late! I'm terribly terribly late!"

A familiar voice broke him out of his thoughts as Zazu flew past him, now the size of a beetle, smaller than before. Now where did he come from?

"Huh? Wait!" Kion called as he tried to pounce at him only to miss as the bird flew into a door the size of a mouse hole. A feint click was heard afterward, locked.

'Now what?' he thought to himself as he looked around the room, looking for a way out.

He then looked back to the coconuts again. He was getting a bit thirsty and maybe a drink might help.

Which coconut did he drink from?

15213222222222.content:
Maybe Kion will get the ability to remove the heads of both himself and any other animals, without causing harm, and attach those heads to any animals body?

He can also attach multiple heads onto the same body, or leave someone headless, or as a disembodied head, but still be able to control their own bodies, even when disembodied, but losing control of the body when either the body gets a new head, or the head is placed on another body. However, Kion can choose whether the animals he uses this ability on can still control their own bodies, even when their heads is attached to someone elses body.

So fx, Kion could remove Bunga's head from his honeybadger-body and attach it to Kion's own lion-body beside his own lion-head; then either let Bunga keep control of his own honeybadger-body, letting Bunga move his honeybadger-body even though it is now headless and having no influence on Kion's lion-body even though his honeybadger-head is attached to it; or remove Bunga's control over his honeybadger-body, leaving his honeybadger-body headless and immobile, and giving Bunga shared control of Kion's own lion-body.

Or, Kion could also fx, choose to remove an elephants head from it's body, attach his own lion-head to the elephant-body and then choose to remove the elephants control over it's elephant-body and letting Kion himself keep control over his own lion-body, thus leaving the elephant as a disembodied head, and giving Kion control of two bodies at the same time; the massive elephant-body that his own tiny lion-head is now attached to, and his own tiny headless lion-body.
This ability can be used even when Kion's own lion-head is not on his lion-body, so Kion could eventually end up controlling a small army of headless bodies, even if he should choose to re-attach his lion-head to his lion-body, until he decides to relinquish control of those bodies, fx by attaching their own heads, or others heads, back on them.

However, just because Kion can control multiple bodies like this, it does NOT mean that he is able to control all those bodies flawlessly right from the get-go. He will always, I repeat, ALWAYS have great difficulty controling/adapting to any new bodies he gets under his control.
Using the above example to explain; it's like this: Kion's lion-head is attached to an elephant-body, so Kion now control the elephant-body, but at the same time, he still also has control over his old lion-body, even though it is now headless. He can feel both what his elephant-body feels and what his headless lion-body feels; however he is used to only having one body, and since he now has to control two, well, that's a difficult matter anytime.

Also, Kion is used to being on four legs, so if he head-swaps with fx an ostrich, he's naturally going to have much more difficulty getting used to walking on two legs instead of four.
15213222222222.title: Kion, the head-swapping lion cub?

choices: Sounds a bit more interesting that the previous choice. I'll take it.
Not much difference from the previous chapter. Choose something else.
152132222222222.content:
How about this: In addition to the abilities from the previous chapter, Kion also gets the ability to grow copies of his own head on either himself and/or any animal whose body is headless or with heads on, courtesy of the abilities mentioned in the previous chapter? So, Kion could choose to fx give himself two more heads for a total of three, or he could choose to place copies of his lion-head on fx the headless bodies of Beshte and Ono, with their consent, of course.

Remember; while Kion can copy his head any number of times, those extra heads won't have copies of Kion's mind inside them. Instead, it's Kion's own mind inside all the heads, meaning his one consiousness is inside all the lion-heads. So, fx, if Kion chooses to give himself two more heads, he will now look through three pairs of eyes at the same time, and since they are all on his own lion-body, it's going to be hard for him to get used to, having triple his normal field of vision.
And if, to use the above example, he places those lion-heads on Beshte's hippo-body and Ono's egret-body respectively, it's going to be even harder for Kion to get used to; because not only does he have to deal with looking in multiple directions at once, (looking through the eyes of both his normal lion-head on his regular lion-body, the lion-head on Beshte's hippo-body, and the lion-head on Ono's egret-body at the same time), but he also has to deal with controling those bodies that his new heads are attatched to, and with Kion's conciousness steering both his normal lion-body, Beshte's big hippo-body and Ono little egret-body at the same time, well, that's hard for him to get used to right away.
Plus, Beshte's and Ono's bodies both have a different body-configuration than what Kion is used to, so that'll be tricky too. For example, Beshte's hippo-body is a lot bigger and bulkier than what Kion is used to, not to mention that a hippo walks and runs in a different way that a lion does, so Kion will have to get used to that too. As for Ono's egret-body, well, he is an egret. So not only will Kion have to get used to walking on two legs, in itself a challenge since he has walked on four legs his whole life, but he'll also have to get used to flying with Ono's egret-body, which will definitely be a challenge, since Kion is used to being on the ground all the time.

Furthermore, all of Kion's new lion-heads, always remain the same size as his regular lion-head, no matter what animal-body the new heads are placed on. So, to use the above example, again, the lion-head on Beshte's hippo-body will therefore look slightly too small on the hippo-body and the lion-head on Ono's egret-body will be a bit oversized on the egret-body, making the lion-head just a little heavy on the smaller egret-body and also making it harder for Kion to learn how to balance/fly with the size and weight of the lion-head slightly bigger/heavier than the optimal for the egret-body.

Finally; all of Kion's lion-heads have the ability to use the Roar of The Elders, no matter which animal-body the lion-heads are on.
